taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Greek isos , equal, and theke , case, alluding to symmetric capsule]

bio:treatment.description: Plants small. Stems irregularly branched. Stem and branch leaves similar, triangular or ovate; margins weakly toothed to entire; ecostate or costa single; medial laminal cells more than 5:1. Seta red-brown, 0.8–2 cm. Capsule suberect, inclined, or rarely erect, symmetric; operculum conic; peristome perfect.
bio:treatment.discussion: Isothecium occurs mainly in temperate to subtropical regions and grows in dense, pendent wefts with creeping stems. The primary stem leaves are squarrose and distant, and erect-spreading, strongly imbricate, or occasionally wide spreading. The setae are smooth; the peristome is yellow.

key_statement.description: Secondary stems irregularly branched, strongly julaceous when dry; stem leaf alar regions extensive, to 1/3 leaf length
Secondary stems irregularly or regularly branched, not julaceous, or if julaceous regularly branched, sometimes dendroid; stem leaf alar regions small, to 1/10 leaf length.
Secondary stems 3 – 15 cm, often dendroid, stipe present, flagelliform tertiary branches rare
Secondary stems 1 – 9 cm, sometimes closely pinnate, stipe short or absent, flagelliform tertiary branches often present.
Secondary stems pinnate or irregularly branched; plants not strongly glossy.
Secondary stems often pinnate, flagelli form branches sometimes present
Secondary stems irregularly branched, flagelliform branches absent (present in I. myosuroides ).
Branchlet leaf apices blunt; margins slightly toothed in apex; stems julaceous
Branchlet leaf apices attenuate ; margins coarsely toothed; stems julaceous or not.
Branches of secondary system sh arp-tipped; stems not julaceous
Branches of secondary system blunt; stems julaceous
